I went to a ton of specialists including cardiologists who finally diagnosed me with a condition called "vaso vagal syncope" and prescribed medication to prevent the attacks. I researched this condition over and over again and learned how all the different medical treatments interacted, even asking if one class of drugs was OK to take with another class of drugs, which the doctors weren't even sure of.   I was finally able to determine that a less potent muscle relaxant that I had known about but hadn't been given would stop the attacks and finally, after fifteen years of labor I stopped having the attacks that would occur every few months for hours that left me bedridden. Text_Numeracy: I remember a few years ago when I had a severe allergic reaction to a certain medication I was prescribed. I recognized the symptoms immediately and knew to seek medical attention right away. I was able to communicate effectively with the healthcare providers about my medical history and the medications I was taking, which played a crucial role in my quick recovery. This experience reinforced the importance of being proactive and informed about my health.
Text_Anxiety: I feel most anxious when visiting the doctor's office because I worry that my health may not be as good as I hope it is despite all the prescription drugs I take regularly. I fear that my lack of physical activity may have negative consequences on my overall well-being. The uncertainty of what the doctor may discover during the visit triggers my anxiety levels.
Text_TrustPhys: I trust my primary care physician because they have comprehensive knowledge of my medical history and the medications I am prescribed. They always take the time to listen to my concerns and always provide me with thoughtful and personalized care. However, I do sometimes question their recommendations when it comes to trying new medications or treatment options, as I am very cautious about introducing new substances into my body. Overall, though, I trust my primary care physician due to the ongoing relationship we have built over time.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I believe I have a good understanding of basic health information and services necessary to make appropriate health decisions. I regularly consult with my primary care physician and take multiple prescription medications as prescribed. However, I acknowledge that there is always room for improvement, especially in terms of incorporating more physical activity into my routine. Overall, I prioritize living in the best possible health and strive to make informed choices regarding my well-being.
